data.text: How Do You Charge Your Devices When You Go On a Bike Adventure?
Hi guys .. A “rookie” question .. when you go for your bike adventures, how do you charge your devices ??
Solar panels and public-access outlets when needed.
data.author: Hunter Blackthorne

data.text: Anker battery bank 20100 mAh
data.author: David Bonetti

data.text: Anker has even a 30000mAh. We use that on all our adventures
data.author: Wim Broens

data.text: that's awesome I'll have to upgrade when this one expires
data.author: David Bonetti

data.text: - can you share a link? The largest I can find is 26800mAh. By the way, it makes a lot of sense to have and use two, even smaller ones. And with the large, always take recharging time into account, any fast charging capabilities are worth their price.
data.author: Marcin Kysiak

data.text: Depending on the situation usually 4x 30.000 mah powerbanks and a 5 port 150 watt charger for if i can recharge from a powersource to charge my main phone and navigation phone and 4 ports for the powerbanks all charge within 8 hours i can do 3 weeks to 1 month without a recharge from the wall this way
data.author: Menno Pieters

data.text: If its summer then 2 powerbanks and 2 solar panels
data.author: Menno Pieters

data.text: restaurants, train stations, public plugs, camping bathrooms,power bank are the best. solar panels gives you limited supplay for telephone and dynamo hub mostly is a romatic idea.
data.author: Jo En Pausa

data.text: I bring a power bank
data.author: Jeff Stone

data.text: I've a Surly..it's got Son dynamo hub... charges Garmin and phone...got solar panel on back panniers for sunny places which I charge battery bank so got power at hand
data.author: Paul Williams

data.text: Solar panel and battery bank
data.author: Sol Findley

data.text: Mine used AA batteries.
data.author: Robert Clark

data.text:
Jefe dynamo and Klite kit! https://youtu.be/-O9dhq1YkHM
kLite Dynamo Bikepacking Light + Charging System | In-Depth Review | Bikepacker Ultra V2
youtube.com
data.author: Michael Fagan

data.text: Anker battery banks. Plus my phones were made recently so have newish batteries.
data.author: Eric Knudstrup

data.text: It depends how far you going and how remote and most of all what is your electronic dependency. I ride with minimum dependency. A mobile phone kept charged but switched off, retained for emergencies only. A small tablet for back up mapping (map.me) and for taking cheap and cheerful photos for posting when opportunity allows. So I use a large power bank and charge it where I can. I suggest travel by bicycle is inherently a desire to escaped the bonds of society if only for a little while. Go as light as possible, in terms of electronic dependency, keep it simple. Go well, cheers, Simon.
data.author: Simon Dodding

data.text: Good advice Simon electronics are inherently heavy .
data.author: Grant McKern

data.text: True Grant and a distraction from the freedoms cycling provides. Electronics also add weight to the other burdens carried as conformists to societies requirements. Casting them aside, as much as possible, frees the individual to go, to seek and sometimes to find. But it is not the finding that matters, what matters is the desire to look. If you have no where you need to be you can never consider yourself lost, that is the true joy of travelling by bicycle. Don’t go for the purpose of getting somewhere, go just for going itself. I miss the open trail.
data.author: Simon Dodding

data.text: I use an add on hib dynamo called a Spin Up. Works great!
data.author: Brent Davis

data.text: Campsites and cheekiness.
data.author: Neil Hornby

data.text: 2 small Anker batteries (primary plus backup) for day use if needed, 4 station usb charger for nighttime, Voltaic solar charger (only bring this if I know there will not be any power at night to charge the Ankers - I’m in the US so it doesn’t get used very often anymore since I got the batteries).
data.author: John Goldman

data.text: Notebook and pen,tell everybody about it when you get home.
data.author: Neil Hornby

data.text: 1. Hub dynamo connected to a sinewave revolution. 2. 6 W solar cells strapped over my back panniers. 3. Powerbanks that I charge if I eat at a restaurant or spend some time in a shop or so.
data.author: Per Sjunnesson

data.text: same here. Make sure the power banks do pass through charging, like voltaic.
data.author: Gerald Prokop

data.text: Solar panel suoaki 28w
data.author: Stéphane Sintès

data.text: So big powerbank))
data.author: Turgay Keleş

data.text: Use a Powerbank. With 10'000mAh you charge a lot.
data.author: Patrick Niederhauser

data.text: Hub dynamo. And grab a few minutes of power in restaurants and cafes
data.author: Simon Owens

data.text: It depends on if you are camping, wild camping, use warmshowers and similar etc. I mainly stay with hosts, but also in hostels and if there is no other opportunity in B&B or hotels, though I have no problems to charge my batteries - even the one for my e-bike, but I also carry two minor powerbanks with me, because I use "gps" all the time. In addition to those, I am also planning to have solar panels this time, because I start during summer month and I am going South.
data.author: Dorothee Hildebrandt

data.text: Two powerbanks (so that I can recharge one and use the other). Replacement battery for the headlight. That can keep me going for two weeks.
data.author: Marcin Kysiak

data.text: I over depend on my dynamo and hope it never stops working. It hasn’t yet
data.author: Travis M Hodgdon

data.text: Son dynamo and Cycle to charge
data.author: Viviane Lanciers

data.text: Solar panels
data.author: Nicolas Ossysek

data.text: Take a fast-charging battery pack, and recharge the battery pack in cafes etc.
data.author: Simon Lambourn

data.text: Coffee shops and bars.
data.author: Kevin Merrill

data.text: Stop at cafes middle of the morning: charging power bank and phone, wash a bit, refill water bottles, take a bit of toilet paper. All for €1 on average. It's a deal.
data.author: Muriel Zaccuri

data.text:
https://www.powerfilmsolar.com/
Lightweight, Thin, Flexible Solar Panels
powerfilmsolar.com
data.author: Doug Finkbeiner

data.text: Depends on the trip. If I expect to stay in hotels at least every few days then I bring a large battery bank. If I think it's going to be mostly camping I bring a solar charger with a small battery bank. Regardless, charge up every chance you get if you're dependant on your electronics for navigation, etc.
data.author: Aimee White

data.text: I just used powerbanks and then charged those whenever I could. I have 2 cheap light small 20,000 mha and 2 30,000
data.author: Gerald Raton

data.text: Im going to do my first “gravel” adventure for 10days ( wild camping ) so I think powerbank will be the best option ! 👍 Thank you all
data.author: Tiago Leal

data.text: Doesn't anyone bicycle tour to just get away from everything? I did most of my long touring in the 80, early 90. ONLY thing i needed to charge was my SLR batteries and as carried 2 means i needed electricity at most one a week. do you really need a garmin, a phone, a laptop ? just asking
data.author: Richard Reitman

data.text: We do need all of this for example because we work while we tour. There is many ways of bike Touring. If you prefer a break of everything that's great but maybe the post writer does not. If we keep on imposing our lifestyle to others and tell people what to do then how can the community stay diverse?
data.author: Iris Mueller

data.text: I stop at a local coffee shop. Support the local economy by buying a coffee and maybe a snack. All while I plug in my laptop. Has worked all over the world for me, such as in Brazil, Mexico, Syria, Albania, Cambodia, Indonesia, India and many other countries.
data.author: Claus Andersen

data.text: yip, its the trustafarians and their gadgets!
data.author: Rene Ordman

data.text: just watch and phone !!
data.author: Tiago Leal

data.text: Powerbank, coffeshops.
data.author: Peter Lehman

data.text: At hotel at night
data.author: Len DeMoss

data.text: While cycling, I use my SON hub dynamo to charge a compact battery unit which has a USB port, from which I recharge portable devices.
data.author: Paul McMahon

data.text: Out the door. On the wall.
data.author: Tom Sailor

data.text: I carry a 5 port usb mains plug for when i have mains power available, a powerbank and ( depending on the length of the trip) small solar panels. All my devices can charge from usb however, my phone isnt too happy charging from solar so, use a powerback to charge that and charge the powerbank during the day. My small solar panels fit nicely onto my bike panniers. If i am going light with inline bags then, i can still fit one on the bar bag and potentially, one on the back too.
data.author: Michael Richards

data.text: I have 2 power banks 20000mah. My brother has another 2 of the same and we also have a solar charger. We also carry 2 fast charge power plugs and leads. We travel Scotland alot and most cafes and food places will let you charge up. Campsites also have areas to charge items.
data.author: Kevin S Litt

data.text: What are fast charge power plus please ?
data.author: Rene Ordman

data.text: ,plug, auto correct changed the spelling
data.author: Kevin S Litt

data.text: , thanks, got it!
data.author: Rene Ordman

data.text: I usually carry gasoline fueled generator,
data.author: Vaibhav S Prakash

data.text: Campsites and the lightest powerbank I could find for emergencies only.
data.author: Sarah Delafortrie

data.text: Tourist offices (at least in France. The Spanish ones were mean and didn’t allow)
data.author: Ashley Hold

data.text: I have a syno hub. Nice to have the independence if electrical plug-in not available.
data.author: Knute Hankins

data.text: I have 4 port USB charger to charge 4 items simultaneously. I also have two powerbanks with pass through capability. I can charge everything in one night and then I can "survive" with the powerbanks for 4 days. I also have an USB hub on my bike and a solar panel when I go into the wild.
data.author: Ralf Lopian

data.text: Had a dynamo hub and hated it, like riding with the brakes on. Now I use two power banks, one has a small solar panel on it so it charges all day as I ride or can directly solar charge a device a little in a pinch. Make the most of public outlets when you find them.
data.author: Mike Johnson

data.text: At the Hotels expense, 2 batteries and 2 chargers 😎😎😎
data.author: Raymond Stevens

data.text: Solar panels are (in combination with a power bank) a good option. I've learned from a great hiking woman to spend my lunch breaks in churches. There's always a power outlet to snip in my phone charger ... of course I always recompensate that service with some euros.
data.author: Jochen Frank

data.text: solar panel
data.author: Andrea Collisson
